etymologies: Old English w(e)orth (adjective and noun), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch waard and German wert

definitions: equivalent in value to the sum or item specified
shortDefinitions: equivalent in value to sum or item specified

definitions: sufficiently good, important, or interesting to justify a specified action; deserving to be treated or regarded in the way specified

examples.text: the museums in the district are well worth a visit

shortDefinitions: sufficiently good, important, or interesting to justify specified action

definitions: used to suggest that the specified course of action may be advisable

examples.text: a meat and potato dish that's worth checking out

shortDefinitions: used to suggest that specified course of action may be advisable

definitions: having income or property amounting to a specified sum
shortDefinitions: having income or property amounting to specified sum

definitions: the value equivalent to that of someone or something under consideration; the level at which someone or something deserves to be valued or rated

examples.text: they had to listen to every piece of gossip and judge its worth

shortDefinitions: value equivalent to that of person or thing under consideration

definitions: an amount of a commodity equivalent to a specified sum of money

examples.text: he admitted stealing 10,000 dollars' worth of computer systems

shortDefinitions: amount of commodity equivalent to specified sum of money

definitions: the amount that could be achieved or produced in a specified time

examples.text: the companies have debts greater than two years' worth of their sales

shortDefinitions: amount that could be achieved or produced in specified time

examples.text: he is noble and gains his position by showing his inner worth
